docs.lead_paragraph: Falling Dollar and Deficit Are Expected to Draw Fire The Bush administration is expected to come under fire for a plunging dollar and a surging budget deficit when a two-day meeting of finance ministers from the Group of 7 industrialized nations begins today. Though committed to a ''strong dollar,'' Treasury Secretary John W. Snow is fending off European leaders who fear the dollar has fallen so far against the euro that European exports will soon be in jeopardy. [Page C3.]

headline.main: PepsiCo Reports Earnings Climbed 30% in Quarter

docs.abstract: PepsiCo says that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 30 percent, largely because of strong sales of noncarbonated beverages like Gatorade and salty snacks at Frito-Lay; net income rises to $897 million, or 51 cents a share; total revenue rises 9.4 percent, to $8.07 billion; for year, earnings per share rise 21 percent, to $2.01, revenue rises 7.4 percent (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PepsiCo said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 30 percent, largely because of strong sales of noncarbonated beverages like Gatorade and salty snacks at Frito-Lay. Consumers' continued concerns about nutrition and obesity contributed to sales of product lines marketed to the health-conscious. Those products helped PepsiCo post solid growth in each of its major business units.

headline.main: Study Details 30-Year Increase in Calorie Consumption

docs.abstract: Study conducted for Centers for Disease Control and Prevention looks at 30 years of Americans' eating habits and pins down how many more calories, carbohydrates and fats are eaten daily; finds that from 1971 to 2000, women increased their caloric intake by 22 percent, men by 7 percent; much of change is found to be due to increase in amount of carbohydrates that are eaten; findings come at time when public health officials are concerned about national epidemic of obesity; graphs (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: We knew we ate more; we knew we had gained weight. Now a new study that looked at 30 years of Americans' eating habits has pinned down how many more calories, carbohydrates and fats are eaten daily. From 1971 to 2000, the study found, women increased their caloric intake by 22 percent, men by 7 percent.

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.abstract: Letter from Andrew C Brisco III (Sugar Assn) says group shares concerns of Kelly D Brownell and Marion Nestle (Jan 23 Op-Ed) regarding importance of reversing worldwide trends in obesity, but notes that sugar consumption has declined over last 30 years, while obesity has risen
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Sugar Association shares the concerns of Kelly D. Brownell and Marion Nestle (''The Sweet and Lowdown on Sugar,'' Op-Ed, Jan. 23) regarding the importance of reversing the worldwide trends in obesity. Their opinions provide precise evidence in support of our concerns regarding the World Health Organization report ''The Expert Consultation on Diet, Nutrition and the Prevention of Chronic Diseases.'' Nutrition policy must be based on the strength of reproducible and published scientific evidence. Sugar consumption has declined over the last 30 years, while obesity has risen. It is difficult understanding how these experts could suggest an obvious relationship between sugar consumption and obesity.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The Sugar Association shares the concerns of Kelly D. Brownell and Marion Nestle (''The Sweet and Lowdown on Sugar,'' Op-Ed, Jan. 23) regarding the importance of reversing the worldwide trends in obesity. Their opinions provide...

docs.abstract: Matt Jordan letter on Jan 20 Jane Brody Personal Health column about weight gain in America holds that weight-loss establishment does not support realistic weight loss programs (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Personal Health column ''The Widening of America, or How Size 4 Became a Size 0'' (Jan. 20): I once weighed 290 pounds but shed almost a third of my weight simply by exercising and eating a well-balanced diet. Many other obese Americans, however, are unwilling to face a similar reality. The variety of diet drugs and gimmicks on the market is bewildering, and Americans are spending billions of dollars a year on them. Yet they just don't seem to be working.

docs.abstract: Editorial scores efforts by Bush administration and American food industry to change World Health Organization plan to fight obesity; deplores administration and sugar industry opposition to urging nations to limit advertising directed at children encouraging unhealty diets
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the hit films at Sundance this year was a documentary called ''Super Size Me,'' about a healthy man -- the film's director -- who decided to see what would happen if he ate nothing but super-sized McDonald's food for 30 days. His weight ballooned, his cholesterol rose, and his liver functions began to erode -- warning signs of a number of chronic diseases that, like obesity itself, have reached epidemic proportions in this country. According to the World Health Organization, those diseases, including cardiovascular disease, Type 2 diabetes and certain cancers, are now part of a major shift in the cause of death around the world. Old-fashioned communicable diseases, like malaria, are being eclipsed by noncommunicable diseases caused by a dramatic change in diet. Even poor countries plagued by malnutrition are at risk for what the W.H.O. calls a malnutrition ''of excess.'' There are 300 million obese adults in the world, some 750 million more who are overweight and 22 million overweight or obese children under the age of 5.

headline.main: Colorado Takes Strides to Polish Thin and Fit Image

docs.abstract: Colorado for years has been leanest state in nation but obesity rate rose to nearly 17 percent of adult population in 2002 and has more than doubled over last decade; only 10 states did worse in 2002 in holding down or reducing number of severely overweight residents; state is seeking to counteract trend with fitness programs; former Stapleton International Airport on Denver's east side is being renovated as planned community promoting active life-style; photos, map, table (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone here has buns of steel and rock-hard abs laced across the zero-fat body of a vegan marathon runner. Everyone hikes and bikes and has climbed Pikes Peak. That is not really true, of course. But as a stereotype, it resonates and lingers -- like the absurd idea that New Yorkers are rude or Californians are flaky -- because it has always been easy to find an example that makes it seem true.

docs.abstract: Article on drug industry's funding of new guielines developed by Texas to treat schizophrenics, often with costlier new drugs developed by same companies; 10 companies contributed and several then paid for meetings around country to urge other states to follow Texas lead; probe developed after Pennsylvania investigator Allen L Jones looked into bank account set up by state officials to collect grants from drug companies; Jones, who says he was removed from probe because of industry influence, brought information to Health and Human Services Department, which requested FBI investigation; Texas guidelines advise doctors to use one of five new anti-psychotics unless they explain in writing why older drug is better; drug costs have ballooned as result; photos of Allen Jones and Dr Anthony F Lehman, who led panel that wrote alternate guidelines without industry financing; role of industry executives and Jones's own lawsuit detailed (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE drug industry has created vast markets for products like Viagra, Celebrex and Vioxx by spending billions of dollars on consumer advertising. But to sell medicines that treat schizophrenia, the companies focus on a much smaller group of customers: state officials who oversee treatment for many people with serious mental illness. Those patients -- in mental hospitals, at mental health clinics and on Medicaid -- make states among the largest buyers of antipsychotic drugs.

headline.main: BackTalk; Elitism in Youth Sports Yields Physical Fatness

docs.abstract: Ken Reed BackTalk column contends that US sports programs for youths favor only exceptional athletes and do not offer physical fitness solutions for less talented children, exacerbating already epidemic national obesity problem; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: We're fat. In fact, as a country, we've never been fatter. Today, as we prepare for the ultimate couch potato experience -- the Super Bowl -- it is sobering to note that almost 65 percent of adults in the United States are either overweight or obese. That is sad news. But what is even sadder is our children are on pace to be significantly fatter than we are by the time they reach adulthood. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that the percentage of children ages 6 to 11 who are overweight has increased nearly 300 percent the past 25 years. The numbers are nearly identical for teenagers.
